anime.description: The surreal comedy centers around the friendship of high school boys.

tag.name: seinen
tag.description: Seinen, literally "young man", is one of the main demographic classifications applied to manga, and, by extension, to anime, especially manga-based ones. As the name implies, seinen works are marketed primarily to an audience of young men; the age range commonly understood to be the target of such works goes roughly from 17 to somewhere in the 40s.

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility. If the parent material was classified under multiple audiences over time (for example, it was originally shounen, but then as the plot changed and became more mature, it was reclassified as seinen), and the anime adapts parent material time periods covering multiple audiences, we tag all audiences covered by the anime adaptation.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: parody
tag.description: Anime that imitate other stories (can be from TV, film, books, historical events, ...) for comic effect by exaggerating the style and changing the content of the original. Also known as spoofs. It can also refer to when whole elements of one work are lifted out of their context and reused.

tag.name: shounen ai
tag.description: Shounen Ai means boys love, and thus explores what happens when two boys (or men) fall in love. This is not to be mistaken for http://anidb.net/t2723 [Yaoi] which is (or, at least, how this term is often used by the western audience) used in adult works. This is not; that means there is no graphical sex. The female version is http://anidb.net/t2782 [Shoujo Ai].

tag.name: manga
tag.description: Manga is the lifeblood that drives the anime industry. Everything and its mother is based on manga. However! There are exceptions where the manga was not the basis for the anime. It`s common practice to make manga adaptations of many popular anime, there`s a manga based on Evangelion, and two (one shounen and one shoujo) based on each of Escaflowne and Mahou Tsukai Tai. Also it`s quite common to release manga and anime versions of a story in parallel, for instance Nadesico and Shoujo Kakumei Utena. There are also cases where an anime continues in a manga, as in the case of Angel Beats! and Angel Beats: Heaven`s Door, or reverse. See also http://anidb.net/t6493 [manhua] and http://anidb.net/t5010 [manhwa].

tag.name: comedy
tag.description: Anime whose central struggle causes hilarious results. These stories are built upon funny characters, situations and events. A comedy anime is laced with humour and sets out to provoke laughter from the audience. Japanese humour can be a bit strange to westerners, so if you`re new to this type of humour, just bear with it; it`ll most likely grow on you if you`re a fan of other kinds of comedy.

tag.name: romance
tag.description: Romance describes a story that deals with love between two or more characters typically also having an optimistic ending. Romance is also a difficulty encountered when creating a harem.

tag.name: short episodes
tag.description: Short episodes are regular episodes that are much shorter than the standard length. This means up to and including 10 minutes; shows with episodes that are 11 to 20 minutes in length are http://anidb.net/t6494 [half-length episodes] instead. Not to be confused with http://anidb.net/t6349 [multi-segment episodes], which are regular episodes that are split into several short segments (parts), usually with separate titles and independent storylines.

tag.name: gender bender
tag.description: Term used to refer to a person who takes on the role of their opposite gender. This often only reaches to the extent of cross-dressing (involving physical appearance and clothing only), but in rarer cases, involves a total gender swap (which seems to be more common in anime) - where the willing or unwilling victim receives a body opposite of their original gender (either permanently or temporarily), with all natural parts per their new body fully (or just all-out amply) included. Example of cross-dressing gender bender: "Maria+Holic" Examples of body-swap gender bender: "Kashimashi: Girl meets Girl", "Birdy the Mighty Decode"

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

character.name: Kinoshita-sensei
character.description: Busty homeroom teacher of Asakura, Ishida and remaining students, who in episode 3 is revealed to be a man. He is a father of Nanako.

character.name: Satou
character.description: Busty classmate of Asakura who is in love with him, and hopes to marry him in the future.

character.name: Yamada
character.description: Yamada is a classmate of Ishida and Asakura, with the appearance of a stereotypical nerd, wearing thick glasses and having prominent buck-teeth. Yamada dreams of opening a bookstore with Asakura, but Ishida violently "kills" him in a slapstick fashion every time the subject is brought up; Yamada will always appear unharmed in the next episode. He is a mechanical genius and once built a robot version of himself to fight Ishida. Source: Wiki

character.name: Ishida
character.description: Asakura`s best friend is a tall and stoic young man who speaks in a strong, serious tone. He dreams of opening a flower shop with Asakura after they graduate high school, and reacts violently whenever Yamada tries to get Asakura`s attention. Because of his constant blushing whenever he speaks to Asakura, it is assumed that he has homosexual feelings for his best friend. Source: Wiki

character.name: Asakura
character.description: He is the main character of the story, a high school student who dreams of becoming a teacher. However, his motives are far from pure, as Asakura is obsessed with breasts and wishes to become a teacher so he can constantly be surrounded by attractive female students. Asakura has an afro and speaks with a slight stutter. In class, there is constant competition for Asakura`s attention between his best friend Ishida and fellow student Yamada. Source: Wiki

character.name: Yamaguchi-sensei
character.description: New teacher of Ishida, Asakura and remaining students. Seems to like Asakura way too much.

character.name: Yamada Imouto
character.description: Younger sister of Yamada. She seems to have a crush on Ishida.

character.name: Iron Yamada
character.description: Robot constructed by Yamada in episode 7 to get rid of Ishida.

character.name: Maid
character.description: Co-worker of Alice in Maid Café run by Tenchou.

character.name: Tenchou
character.description: Manager of Maid Café who agreed to hire Ishida for part time job if he will pose as a girl. That is how Alice "was born".

character.name: Alice
character.description: A personality which Ishida had to adopt to get part time job in Maid Café run by Tenchou.

episode.title: あさくらと将来
The Introduction of Asakura
A Introdução do Asakura
Asakura to Shourai
episode.summary: Asakura is high school senior and he`s squarely focused on one thing... boobs. But the rest of his classmates all seem to be focused on him!

episode.title: あさくらと特訓
The Training of Asakura
O Treino do Asakura
episode.summary: Asakura`s future gets further in doubt when his test scores come in. Ishida decides it`s time for some extreme training!

episode.title: あさくらとゾウさん
The Trunk Incident
O Incidente da Tromba
episode.summary: After a long lecture in class, the boys all feel a need to relieve themselves, but they`re surprised by an unexpected guest.

episode.title: あさくらと電話
The Old Friend Fraud
A Fraude do Velho Amigo
episode.summary: Asakura is worried about startup funds, and then everyone gets fraudulent phone calls asking for money.

episode.title: 山口先生の情熱
The Passion of Yamaguchi-sensei
A Paixão do Professor Yamaguchi
episode.summary: Asakura and friends have a new teacher in class, and he`s fired up about education! But can he deal with students like these?

episode.title: 奈々子とあさくら
Nanako and Asakura
Nanako e Asakura
episode.summary: Asakura saves Kinoshita-sensei`s daughter from a traffic accident, and it would seem to be fate, but something is missing from the equation.

episode.title: 石田とあさくら
Ishida & Asakura
Ishida e Asakura
episode.summary: Ishida try to save Asakura which fell from the bridge. With burst of superhuman strength he throws him into atmosphere, accidentally hitting an UFO. Naked Asakura (whose clothes burned during flight through atmosphere) and Ishida are then found by teachers and colleagues, who confirm, that somebody shot down an UFO. Later on all girls with Kinoshita-sensei are on board of another UFO, but planned alien invasion on Earth was stopped by Kinoshita-sensei.

episode.title: 石田とスマイル
Ishida and Smiling
Ishida e Sorriso
episode.summary: Ishida, to his shock, discovers that one has to be able to smile to run a flower shop, so Asakura and friends try to help him learn.

episode.title: 兄と妹
Brother and Sister
Irmão e Irmã
episode.summary: Ishida kills Yamada again on the way to school, and his little sister vows revenge.

episode.title: 山田とアリス
Yamada and Alice
Yamada e Alice
episode.summary: Yamada has a thing for Alice, the new maid at the maid cafe. When he discovers Ishida frequenting the shop, the battle lines are drawn!

episode.title: アリスとあさくら
Alice and Asakura
Alice e Asakura
episode.summary: Ishida needs to earn 10 million yen to open up his flower shop, so he takes a job at a local cafe.

episode.title: 石田とアイアン山田
Ishida and Iron Yamada
Ishida e o Yamada de Ferro
episode.summary: Yamada constructs a robot assassin to get rid of his rival, but it doesn`t go as planned.

episode.title: 総集編
Episode S1
episode.summary: As in the beginning of every episode Ishida and Asakura talk in their classroom. This time Asakura asks Ishida about the ending of anime.
